A B S T R A C T
In this paper, a novel all-optical plasmonic switch is presented. For the proposed structure, a nano-disk resonator coupled to parenthesis-shaped adjunctions and perpendicular metal–insulator–metal waveguides are used. The insulator which is used here, is an optically nonlinear Kerr-type material (InGaAsP). The data and control pulses are injected to the horizontal and vertical waveguides, respectively. Allocating two separate waveguides for the data and control signals prevents these signals from interfering with each other. One of the main benefits of the proposed switch is that a single wavelength can be used for the data and control signals. It prevents the amplitude modulation of the output signal and eliminates the need for harmonic suppression filters. The finite difference time domain (FDTD) method is used for numerical investigation of the switch. Based on the numerical simulations, the switch can operate for control pulses as narrow as 3 ps at 1028 nm. In addition to FDTD, analytical formulas have also been presented to model the switch, which are in excellent agreement with FDTD results. To provide a better perspective, besides the conventional frequency domain analysis, the time domain simulations are also presented. The main advantages of the proposed topology are: the ability to use an identical wavelength for data and control pulses (which originates from the novel resonator shape), having separate and isolated input and output data and control ports, requiring a small footprint area of 1.37 μm2, the simplicity of fabrication due to its simple and symmetric structure and finally the robustness of the design, where other nonlinear materials with higher Kerr indices can also be easily used to redesign the switch.
. Introduction
Surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) are dispersive electromagnetic aves coupled to the electrons of plasma in the metal and dielectric nterface [1]. SPPs open up a new pathway for applications in miniaurized optical devices due to their notable ability to overcome the iffraction limit and manipulating light in a nanoscale domain [2]. ccordingly, almost all of the passive and active photonic devices hat are designed and fabricated based on the photonic crystal (PhC) tructures including PhC filters [3], splitters [4–7], sensors [8], inersections [9,10], demultiplexers [11], slow light buffers [12], logic ates [13], waveguides [14], switches [15–17] etc., can be redesigned sing SPPs with much more compact sizes. In this direction, various lasmonic filters [18–21], sensors [22–24], demultiplexers [25–27], ntersections [28,29], optical modulators [30,31], logic gates [32–34], witches [35,36] have been proposed in the literature. Since the scatterng and absorption cross sections of nanoparticles are enhanced at the lasmon resonance, plasmonic structures can also be used to increase he efficiency of solar cells [37,38]. Among the plasmonic structures, plasmonic switches are one of the key devices in the area of optical communications. In addition to plasmonic switches, other types of AOSs based on the fiber grating structures [41–43], cascaded long period fiber gratings [44], graphene [45, 46], metamaterial structures [47,48], mixed crystal topologies [49], etc. can also be designed. Based on the technique which is used to design optical switches, these components are classified into various types of electro-optic switches [50,51], thermo-optic switches [52, 53], and all-optical switches (AOSs) [54,55]. AOSs have remarkable advantages such as fast signal processing ability, immunity to electromagnetic interference and low cost fabrication capability. Consequently, these devices have attracted much attention in all-optical communication systems. Plasmonic AOSs can use optical nonlinear materials for the active control of optical signals. For instance, metal–insulator– metal (MIM) WGs coupled with ring resonators [56–58], nano-disk resonators (NDRs) [59,60], stub resonators [61,62] and other types of resonators [63–66]. All of the aforementioned switches published in the literature use a single WG for both data and control signals. Due to lack of isolation between the data and control signals in these techniques, they are not much desirable for integrated optics.
We have tried to find solutions for having two isolated WGs for the data and control signals [67,68]. In [67] and [68], an asymmetric directional coupler and two perpendicular WGs have been used, respectively. However, based on the knowledge of the authors, in none of the mentioned plasmonic all-optical switches the time domain behavior of the switches has been investigated, while we have demonstrated the switching operation in time domain. In most of the mentioned papers usually it is assumed that the control signal creates a refractive index change. The transmission curves for the original refractive index and the perturbed refractive index case are usually presented to justify its operation as a switch. However, as we have recently shown in [64], things are not as simple as that. It is necessary to present time domain simulations to prove the correct operation of a switch when the Kerr effect is used. The self and cross modulation of control and data signals, and harmonic generation are the most important optical phenomena that are neglected in the frequency domain analysis. Furthermore, it should be noted that the refractive index change is not uniform in all of the resonator areas. This fact reduces the accuracy of the aforementioned method.
In this paper, an AOS based on an improved nano-disk resonator (INDR) [69] and two isolated WGs incorporating nonlinear Kerr materials has been designed and investigated. One of the WGs (the horizontal WG) is allocated to the data signal and another one (the vertical WG) passes the control signal. Using two separate WGs in the proposed structure results in an appropriate isolation between the data and control signals. It should be mentioned that, here the wavelengths of data and control signals can be equal. This provision eliminates the amplitude modulation of the output signal. In other words, the proposed switch does not need a filter for removing the harmonics. This decrease the total size of the structure and reduces the fabrication complexity. The metal and nonlinear insulator materials which are used to design the proposed AOS are silver and InGaAsP, respectively. Numerical simulations are performed using the finite difference time domain (FDTD) method. Furthermore, analytical formulas have also been proposed for obtaining the hysteresis curves of the nonlinear plasmonic structures which are in excellent agreement with FDTD results.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows: In Section 2, the proposed analytical formulas which are used for modeling the switching behavior of the switch have been presented. Section 3 investigates the building blocks of the switch which are dubbed as ‘‘Filter A’’ and ‘‘Filter B’’. In Section 4, the designed AOS and its performance are introduced and comprehensively studied, respectively. The two final sections (Sections 5 and 6) are devoted to the comparisons and conclusions, respectively.

sections.heading: 4. The proposed AOS
sections.text: In this section, the main structure of the designed AOS has been investigated. As mentioned before, by changing the refractive index of the existing Kerr material in INDR and WGs, the switching operation can be obtained. First, the previously designed filters (Filter A and Filter B) have been combined. Thereafter, the effect of the control signal on the refractive index of the Kerr material and switching mechanism of the designed AOS has been investigated. Then, by sweeping some of the structural parameters, the effect of structural parameters on the data signal have been considered. At the end of this section, the time domain simulations and the related considerations are studied.

sections.heading: 4.2. Investigation of the structural parameters’ effects
sections.text:
In this sub-section, some of the structural parameters including the radius of the NDR (r1), the gap between the NDR and parenthesis adjunctions (g) and the width of the parenthesis adjunctions (d) have been swept and their effects on the transmission spectra of the data signal have been investigated. These variations are shown in Fig. 16. As seen in Fig. 16(a), increasing the r1 value leads to a higher maximum transmittance peak and a higher resonance wavelength. Although the higher maximum transmittance peaks are achieved for r1 > 400 nm, the footprint of the structure increases too. Accordingly, r1 = 400 nm is the most suitable choice due to its acceptable maximum transmittance and its compact size.
The second parameter is ‘‘g’’. Fig. 16(b) shows that by increasing g from 10 nm to 22 nm, the coupling strength between the NDR and parenthesis adjunctions is decreased. In other words, the maximum transmittance value is decreased and the sharpness of the data mode edges is increased. Therefore, to have a trade-off between the design parameters, the value of 16 nm is selected for g. The last parameter is ‘‘d’’. The variation of this parameter is shown in Fig. 16(c). Here, similar to the g parameter, the middle value of d (45 nm) creates a suitable maximum transmittance value and sharp transition edges for the generated mode.
As known, by increasing the size of the resonator in a plasmonic structure, its resonance mode shifts to higher wavelengths with lower maximum transmittance values and higher quality factors. Here, by increasing the d parameter, the size of the parenthesis-shaped resonator
increases. Therefore, there is a suitable trade-off between the two design parameters of the lower maximum transmittance and higher quality factor. This is achieved by considering d = 45 nm.

sections.heading: 4.3. Time domain simulation results of the proposed AOS
sections.text:
After designing the proposed AOS, to provide a better prospect of the switching mechanism, the time domain simulations of the designed switch have been presented. For this purpose, first, it is imperative that the input powers of the DSS and CSS (PIN-data and PIN-control) be determined. Initially, by applying only a continuous-wave at the wavelength of 1028 nm to port 1, PIN-data is selected. Fig. 17(a) shows the variations of the maximum normalized transmission of the data signal for different values of PIN-data. As seen in this figure, by increasing PIN-data, the maximum normalized transmission is decreased. Accordingly, to have a high transmittance value for the data signal, a low PIN-data equal to 1.34 W/μm with a maximum transmittance of 69% has been selected for the DSS. Thereafter, by turning on both the DSS and CSS, the variations of the contrast ratio (CR) have been investigated through changing PIN-control. Here, the CSS is a Gaussian-pulse at the wavelength of 1028 nm. The mentioned variations are shown in Fig. 17(b). This figure shows that when PIN-control is increased, the CR of the output signal increases initially and then decreases. The maximum CR (8.68 dB) occurs at PIN-control = 39.93 W/μm which is selected for designing the proposed AOS.
After selecting PIN-data and PIN-control, the time-domain behavior of the output signal has been investigated. The continuous-wave signal
and the Gaussian-shaped pulse which are used for the DSS and CSS are shown in Figs. 18(a) and (b), respectively. The output signal derived from these two inputs is presented in Fig. 18(c).
As seen in Fig. 18(c), when only the DSS with the input power of 1.34 W/μm is applied (the section from 0 ps to 3 ps), about 0.69 × PIN-data or 0.93 W/μm is transmitted to the output port (port 2). If the Gaussian-pulse of the CSS with the input power of 39.93 W/μm is also ‘‘on’’ (Fig. 18(b)), the transmitted power to the output port (at the range
of 3 ps to 9 ps) is reduced to 0.17 W/μm or 0.126 × PIN-data. In other words, the status of the AOS changes from ‘‘on’’ to ‘‘off’’. Finally, when the control pulse is turned off again (from 9 ps to 12 ps), the AOS returns to its previous state (the ‘‘on’’ state).

sections.heading: 5. Results, comparisons and discussions
sections.text:
In this section, comparisons between the proposed AOS and other works, in terms of characteristic parameters, are performed. Table 2 shows the properties of some AOSs. In this table, the comparison parameters include the types of the Kerr material used along with their nonlinear refractive indexes (n2), the control power intensity (I), the data and control wavelengths (𝜆d and 𝜆c), the transmittances values f the data signals for the ‘‘on’’ and ‘‘off’’ states (Ton and Toff ), the OS sizes and the isolation of data and control WGs. Also, it has been
nvestigated whether the time simulations are performed or not. In [58] ring resonators side-coupled an MIM plasmonic waveguide re used to create an optical switch. One of the ring resonators is illed with a Kerr-type material. In [58], the data and pump signals ave to be injected from a single port. To separate the high intensity ump signal from the low intensity data signals in such designs, very igh performance demultiplexers are needed. In [59] a similar idea is sed, in which the ring resonator is replaced by two disk resonators. n [59], the resonators are located at the arms of a T-junction. The dea is very clever and worth admiring. However, due to using a Tunction a large portion of the signal is reflected backwards. In simple ords, the maximum transmittance is less than 57%. The structure used n [60] uses parallel stubs connected to a main waveguide, one of which s terminated to a disk resonator filled with a Kerr-type material. It lso uses a single waveguide for both signals and needs high precision emultiplexers. The same problem exists in [66]. The references [67] nd [68] are authors’ previous publications. In [67] we have used an symmetric directional coupler which solves the problem of isolated aveguides, but needs a large footprint area. In [68] we have also olved the problem of separate waveguides and footprint area, but the aximum transmission is still less than 64%.
Here, in addition to comparing the control power intensity, the type f Kerr materials is also compared. In order to have fair comparisons,
the dependence of the control power intensity to nonlinear index of the Kerr materials should be considered. If a nonlinear material with a high nonlinear refractive index is used, low control power intensity is needed to change the refractive index of Kerr material. Therefore, it is reasonable that the proposed AOS (due to its lower nonlinear refractive index) needs more control power intensity compared to other works.
As seen in this table, only the proposed switch uses identical data and control wavelengths among the presented works. This issue has been neglected in other designed AOSs, while the time domain simulations in this paper show that choosing two different wavelengths for data and control can cause problems. Other comparison parameters are the transmittance values of the data wavelength for the ‘‘on’’ and ‘‘off’’ states. The difference between the two values shows the 𝛥Trans parameter. As seen, the proposed AOS has the highest transmittance variation between the on and off states among the other works. Also, as mentioned, the proposed AOS consists of two isolated WGs for the data and control wavelengths. This is the reason why the designed AOS has a larger footprint compared to other works. As known, there is a trade-off between the designing parameters. Therefore, although the proposed AOS has a larger size or needs more control power intensity, it has other better properties such as the same data and control wavelengths, separate and isolated data and control ports, simple structure.
In summary, the main novelty of the designed AOS is that by using a combination of an INDR and cross-path MIM WGs a compactsize all-optical switch is obtained which can use a same wavelength for both control and pump signals. This prevents the intermodulation between these signals and reduces harmonic distortion. Contrary to other circuits that use a common WG to pass the data and control signals, this paper uses two separated paths for such signals. In fact, this method prevents cross talk between the data and control ports. It is worth mentioning that in order to verify the correct operation of the proposed switch, its time domain behavior were investigated. sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
A novel structure for achieving the all optical switching mechanism was proposed and investigated in this paper. The structure consisted of an INDR coupled with two cross WGs. The nonlinear Kerr effect was used to procure the switching mechanism and the Kerr material which was used was InGaAsP. It is worth mentioning that sliver was used as the metal material and it was characterized by the Drude model in our numerical simulations. The FDTD method was utilized to simulate the proposed structure and the frequency and time-domain behavior of the switch were considered. In addition to the numerical simulations, an analytical method was also proposed for modeling the hysteresis in optical switches. Such a method was highly consistent with the numerical results obtained using FDTD method. It was shown that the switch can correctly operate for control pulses as narrow as 3ps at 1028 nm. The maximum transmittance value was 76.8% and the footprint area was 1.37 μm2. The proposed AOS due to isolated WGs nd having identical data and control wavelengths has the potential to e used in highly integrated optical circuits.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, a novel all-optical plasmonic switch is presented. For the proposed structure, a nano-disk resonator coupled to parenthesis-shaped adjunctions and perpendicular metal–insulator–metal waveguides are used. The insulator which is used here, is an optically nonlinear Kerr-type material (InGaAsP). The data and control pulses are injected to the horizontal and vertical waveguides, respectively. Allocating two separate waveguides for the data and control signals prevents these signals from interfering with each other. One of the main benefits of the proposed switch is that a single wavelength can be used for the data and control signals. It prevents the amplitude modulation of the output signal and eliminates the need for harmonic suppression filters. The finite difference time domain (FDTD) method is used for numerical investigation of the switch. Based on the numerical simulations, the switch can operate for control pulses as narrow as 3 ps at 1028 nm. In addition to FDTD, analytical formulas have also been presented to model the switch, which are in excellent agreement with FDTD results. To provide a better perspective, besides the conventional frequency domain analysis, the time domain simulations are also presented. The main advantages of the proposed topology are: the ability to use an identical wavelength for data and control pulses (which originates from the novel resonator shape), having separate and isolated input and output data and control ports, requiring a small footprint area of 1.37 μm2, the simplicity of fabrication due to its simple and symmetric structure and finally the robustness of the design, where other nonlinear materials with higher Kerr indices can also be easily used to redesign the switch.
